docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a survey of employers' health care costs misstated the title of Paul Fronstin of the Employee Benefit Research Institute. He is a research associate specializing in health benefits, not the research director.
docs.abstract: Correction of Jan 20 article bout a survey of employers' health care costs

docs.lead_paragraph: Geraldine P. puts in her eight hours each workday as a secretary for a Manhattan office-supply company. But until recently, when her co-workers headed home at 5 P.M., she boarded a bus for La Guardia Airport. ''And it wasn't because I was jet-setting to the Caribbean,'' she said. For seven months Geraldine, along with her mother, Maureen, and her brother Gino, lived in the American Airlines terminal. They washed in airport restrooms, dined at airport snack bars and passed their evenings watching television in airport lounges. At night, they learned to doze under harsh fluorescent lights, but not so deeply that they would be prey to pickpockets. They kept their clothing in shopping bags at their feet. And for the most part, they say, the Port Authority police looked the other way.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Family Regains a Home After Living Lost in La Guardia's Bustle

docs.abstract: Homeless family living in La Guardia Airport is aided by Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, New York Times Neediest Cases Fund beneficiary (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The shares of the American Home Products Corporation and of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. retreated yesterday as the euphoria over a possible merger of the companies began to cool. After rising 17 percent on Tuesday, the stock of American Home Products dropped 3.9 percent yesterday to close at $90.5625. SmithKline's American depository receipts fell 4 percent, to $57.125, enough to create some downward momentum for other drug stocks. The shares of Eli Lilly, Merck, Schering-Plough and Warner-Lambert all dropped yesterday after posting gains on Tuesday.

headline.main: Drug Makers See Decrease In Share Price

docs.abstract: Euphoria over possible merger of American Home Products Corp and SmithKline Beecham PLC begins to cool, and shares of two companies retreat; analysts say one of prime troubling points is American Home Products' legal liabilities from two diet drugs, and fact that it has only $1 billion in product liability insurance; it also faces lawsuits over side effects from its contraceptive device (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lobbyists for big business, small business and health insurance companies today unveiled a $1 million campaign to block bipartisan legislation intended to protect the rights of patients. The lobbyists said such legislation, far from protecting patients, would increase the cost of health care and health insurance, so that many employers would cut back coverage.

headline.main: Business Coalition to Fight Legislation Protecting Patients' Rights

docs.abstract: Lobbyists for big business, small business and health insurance companies plan $1 million drive to block patients rights bills; say bills would increase cost of health care and health insurance, spurring many employers to cut back coverage; Congressional Budget Office forecasts resurgence of health care inflation, with spending rising from current 13.5 percent of gross national product to 15.5 percent by 2008; says laws to protect consumers could raise premiums even more (M)
